facts.text: Appeal filed with special leave granted by Supreme Court on May 18, 1954

anchor.surface_text: special leave granted by this companyrt on the 18th of May, 1954, questioning the companyrectness of the judgment

facts.text: High Court of Punjab delivered judgment and order dated June 25, 1953 dismissing application under section 66(2) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: , questioning the companyrectness of the judgment and order of the High Court of Punjab dated the 25th June, 1953, delivered in an application under section 66  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, whereby the High Court dismissed the appellants application

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal order dated November 4, 1949

anchor.surface_text: the High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that numberquestion of law arose from the order of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dated the 4th November, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant is resident of Simla and forest contractor

anchor.surface_text: The facts are shortly as follows The appellant, who is a resident of Simla, is a forest companytractor and had taken certain forests on lease

facts.text: Appellant took certain forests on lease in 1942-43 in Jubbal State for exploitation

anchor.surface_text: is a forest companytractor and had taken certain forests on lease in 1942-43 in the erstwhile Indian State of Jubbal for exploitation.

facts.text: Work of felling trees and extraction of timber continued up to 1945-46

anchor.surface_text: The work of felling of trees and extraction of timber companytinued up to 1945-46.

facts.text: No profit or loss account prepared for each of four years separately but consolidated balance-sheet and profit and loss account for all four years

anchor.surface_text: No profit or loss account had been prepared for each of the aforesaid four years separately, but a companysolidated balance-sheet and profit and loss account had been drawn up for all the four years.

facts.text: In income-tax returns, income from forest business shown by applying 10% net on sales in relevant years

anchor.surface_text: In the appellants Income-tax returns, the income from the forest business was calculated and shown by applying the rate of ten per cent. net on the sales made in the relevant years.

facts.text: Appellant sold timber in accounting year 1942-43 in Jubbal to Sukh Dial Jagat Ram for Rs. 1,91,000

anchor.surface_text: it transpired that the appellant, who was resident and ordinarily resident in British India, had in the relevant accounting year 1942-43 sold in Jubbal a quantity of timber in one lot to a single party named Sukh Dial Jagat Ram,

facts.text: Sukh Dial Jagat Ram is a firm carrying on business in Abdullapore in district of Ambala

anchor.surface_text: named Sukh Dial Jagat Ram, a firm carrying on business in Abdullapore in the district of Ambala, for a sum of Rs. 1,91,000  rupees one lakh ninety- one thousand .

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessment order dated February 2, 1948 held profit of Rs. 20,967 on sale of timber value Rs. 1,91,000 in 1942-43

anchor.surface_text: By his assessment order dated the 2nd February, 1948, the Income-tax officer held that on the sale of timber of the value of Rs. 1,91,000 during the relevant accounting period 1942-43, the appellant had made a profit of Rs. 20,967.

facts.text: No part of sale proceeds received during relevant accounting period 1942-43

anchor.surface_text: As, however, numberpart of the sale proceeds was received during the relevant accounting period, the income from the forest business, less the statutory exemption of Rs. 4,500 was taken into companysideration only for the purpose of fixing the rate.

facts.text: Profits on sales during 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46 determined by Income-tax Officer

anchor.surface_text: The profits made on sales during the three succeeding accounting periods 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1945-46 were also determined by the Income-tax officer as indicated in his assessment order.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal allowed certain expenses, reduced total income from forest business

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the appellant, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed certain expenses, which had been disallowed by the Income-tax Officer, so that the total income from the forest business was reduced.

facts.text: Profit on sale 1942-43 reduced by AAC from Rs. 20,967

anchor.surface_text: The profit on the sale of timber during the accounting year 1942-43 was accordingly reduced from Rs. 19,767 and the profits for the three succeeding accounting years were proportionately reduced.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal further reduced profits by allowance of Rs. 5,000, profit for 1942-43 Rs. 18,758

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, the profits were further reduced by the allowance of a further sum of Rs. 5,000 so that the profit of the accounting year 1942-43 was finally ascertained and determined to be Rs. 18,758.

facts.text: Out of purchase price Rs. 1,91,000: Rs. 1,25,000 received in cash in Jubbal, Rs. 29,000 in cash in British India, Rs. 3,000 paid to Sita Ram in British India

anchor.surface_text: out of the purchase price of Rs. 1,91,000 for timber sold in the accounting year 1942-43 in the following manner Rs. 1,25,000 received in cash in Jubbal State. Rs. 29,000 received in cash by the appellant in British India. Rs. 3,000 paid in cash in British India to a companytractor named Sita Ram,

facts.text: Sita Ram was a creditor of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: to a companytractor named Sita Ram, who was a creditor of the appellant.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer viewed Rs. 32,000 received in accounting year 1943-44 as including entire profit from 1942-43 sale, assessable under section 4(1)(b)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer took the view that the sums of Rs. 29,000 and Rs. 3,000, aggregating to Rs. 32,000, received in the relevant accounting year 1943-44 included the entire profit that had accrued or arisen to the appellant on the sale of timber in 1942-43 for Rs. 1,91,000 and such profit was assessable to tax under section 4  1   b   iii

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld Income-tax Officer on appeal

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the appellant the Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the decision of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld, held payments tantamount to constructive remittances of profits

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal by the appellant the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal took the same view and dismissed the appeal. The Appellate Tribunal, in agreement with the Income-tax authorities, held that the two payments in British India had been made by the purchaser according to the instructions of the appellant and were companysequently tantamount to companystructive remittances of those amounts from Jubbal State to British India and that the profits,

facts.text: Appellant applied to Tribunal under section 66(1), dismissed August 7, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by the decision of the Appellate Tribunal, the appellant applied to the Appellate Tribunal under section 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, ... the Appellate Tribunal by its order dated 7th August, 1950, dismissed the application

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court of Punjab under section 66(2)

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon applied to the High Count of Punjab under section 66  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922,

facts.text: High Court dismissed application on June 25, 1953 with costs

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated the 25th June, 1953, the High Court dismissed the application with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and circumstances of this case, no real or substantial question of law arises from the order of the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court was justified in dismissing the appellants application under section 66

holdings.text: No real or substantial question of law arises from the order of the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court was justified in dismissing the appellant's application under section 66(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and circumstances of this case, no real or substantial question of law arises from the order of the Appellate Tribunal and the High Court was justified in dismissing the appellants application under section 66

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examined merits of accrual of profit, constructive remittance, presumption of profits in remittances, and found lower tribunals' findings supported by evidence and law, hence no substantial question of law.

holdings.text: Profit accrues or arises on the sale when it takes place (in 1942-43), regardless of when payment is received or outlay recouped.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no getting away from the fact that profit accrues or arises on the sale, which in this case took place in 1942-43. Whatever profit there was, it certainly accrued or arose in that year. The profit on the sale of timber in 1942-43 has since been ascertained at Rs. 18,758.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects argument that profit arises only after recoupment of entire outlay; profit realized on sale per accounting principles.

holdings.text: Remittances from foreign business (Jubbal) to British India are presumed to be out of profits unless contrary shown; presumption applies even if outlay not fully recouped at remittance time; onus on assessee not discharged.

anchor.surface_text: There being this profit, as eventually ascertained, the presumption, according to the cases referred to in the judgment under appeal, will be that the remittances of money from foreign business to British India must be of profits, unless the contrary were shown by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents; distinguishes Bhagwandas Bagla as inapplicable since sale completed and profit anticipated; assessee failed to prove remittances were capital.

holdings.text: The Rs.32,000 payments in British India (Rs.29,000 to assessee, Rs.3,000 to creditor) constitute constructive remittances from Jubbal, as made by purchaser per appellant's instructions; purchaser acted as agent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the tribunal was quite correct in saying that, in the circumstances, the payment was undoubtedly a constructive remittance of money by the appellant from Jubbal to his British India office. Similar considerations apply to the payment of Rs. 29,000 by the purchaser to the assessee himself in British India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances (payment to creditor, affidavit silence) indicate instructions given; direct payment per instructions equals remittance.

holdings.text: The entire profit of Rs.18,758 from 1942-43 sale is included in the Rs.32,000 remitted; not merely proportionate part.

anchor.surface_text: In such a situation the presumption is that the profit was included in the remittances and the decision referred to above can have no application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payments per direction equivalent to remittance after receipt in Jubbal; presumption covers entire profit; distinguishes Turner Morrison as inapplicable.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's finding that Rs.32,000 included entire profit from 1942-43 sale is supported by evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the appellant did not discharge the onus that was on him and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was quite correct in coming to the conclusion that the sum of Rs. 32,000 included the profits made on the sale of timber for Rs. 1,91,000 in the accounting year 1942-43.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee failed to rebut presumption with evidence of capital remittance.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla in support of this contention. There is noforce in this contention, because it may well be that the appellant knew that his party was solvent and sound and in anticipation of the realization of the entire amount, the appellant remitted the entire profit, which he calculated would eventually come in, to British India.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla
precedents.cited_proposition: remittances of sale proceeds are return of initial outlay until entire outlay is recovered and no question of profit arises until then
precedents.cited_holding: the amounts remitted by the agent were the initial outlay and no question of profit could arise until the entire outlay was recovered

precedents.citation: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal. That decision has really noapplication to the facts of the present case. As already stated the two amounts were paid in British India at the direction of the appellant, which means the same thing as if the payment had been by the purchaser and received by the appellant from his purchaser in Jubbal and then remitted by the appellant through the purchaser as his agent to himself and his creditor in British India.

precedents.case_name: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: only a proportionate part of the total profit attributable to the remitted sum is to be regarded as remitted profit
